node.title: Overnight ferry inferno kills dozens, injures scores more
node.description: Many passengers jumped off and swam to shore on the river in southern Bangladesh. The vessel had 800 aboard. One official says the blaze may have started in the engine room.

node.title: Gorbachev says U.S. became "arrogant" after Soviet Union collapsed
node.description: The last Soviet president, who's now 90, said the West then "decided to build a new empire. Hence the idea of NATO expansion."

node.title: DA to seek much shorter sentence for trucker in deadly crash
node.description: Rogel Aguilera-Mederos was given 110 years but millions signed a petition calling for the term to be cut. Celebrities and fellow truckers are also backing him.

node.title: Large fossil found in Nevada could provide insight into aquatic evolution
node.description: It's the largest animal found from that time period, both in the sea and on land, and currently holds the title of first giant animal to ever inhabit Earth.

node.title: United and Delta cancel more than 200 flights due to Omicron virus spread
node.description: United and Delta have collectively canceled more than 200 flights on Christmas Eve.

node.title: Christmas Decor surprises families with free and festive home makeovers
node.description: A holiday decorations company surprises 200 families every year.

node.title: Texas board withdraws pardon recommendation for George Floyd
node.description: Floyd, who was from Houston, was killed last year by former Minneapolis police officer Derek Chauvin.

node.title: Treatment helps most chemotherapy patients prevent hair loss
node.description: Hair loss can have an emotional impact on all people during cancer treatments, but there's a procedure — ice caps — that helps prevent that in most patients.

node.title: 40 federal judges confirmed in 2021; Biden nominates two more
node.description: This is the largest number of confirmed judges since Reagan was president.

node.title: CDC shortens isolation time for health care workers with COVID-19
node.description: Federal officials say the change was motivated by the rapid spread of the Omicron variant and a staffing crunch at hospitals nationwide.

node.title: Tesla video games will no longer work in cars that are moving
node.description: A new software patch that Tesla plans to release will stop Passenger Play from activating when a vehicle is in drive.

node.title: After 25 years, DNA could solve JonBenét Ramsey murder case
node.description: The murder of the 6-year-old beauty queen is a cold case that still haunts many Americans.

node.title: This site just beat Google as most visited online destination
node.description: Social media platform's explosive growth vaults it past the search giant and Facebook as most trafficked site.

node.title: 5 teens charged in carjacking of Representative Mary Gay Scanlon
node.description: Five teenagers have been charged in the armed carjacking​ of U.S. Representative Mary Gay Scanlon in Philadelphia.

node.title: Times Square New Year's Eve celebration scaled back
node.description: The famous celebration will host less audience members and require them to wear masks and be fully vaccinated.

node.title: Miracle dog survives after owner dies in Fenn treasure hunt
node.description: Rescue team finds Leo in freezing wilderness after 10 days alone.

node.title: Man known as the "Unabomber" moved to prison medical facility
node.description: Theodore "Ted" Kaczynski, 79, was moved to the U.S. Bureau of Prison's FMC Butner medical center in eastern North Carolina on December 14, according to bureau spokesperson Donald Murphy.

node.title: Amazon will give workers more power to organize a union
node.description: Nation's second-largest employer is facing a restless workforce as it continues to expand during the pandemic.

node.title: Outcome reached in trial of Kim Potter, former officer who shot Daunte Wright
node.description: Potter gave emotional testimony in her own defense, saying she meant to grab her Taser instead of her gun.

node.title: Trump asks Supreme Court to stop release of White House records
node.description: Trump's lawyers said the request from the January 6 select committee is "strikingly broad" and "untethered from any valid legislative purpose."

node.title: More asphyxiation deaths linked to adult bed rails
node.description: Consumers urged not to use hundreds of thousands of devices sold nationwide at medical supply stores and online.

node.title: Expert advice on travel insurance for holiday flyers
node.description: With so many travelers returning to the skies as the coronavirus​ pandemic persists, CBS News senior travel adviser Peter Greenberg says airports will be busy and understaffed.​

node.title: Joan Didion, revered author, dies at 87
node.description: Didion's publisher, Penguin Random House, announced the author's death on Thursday. She died from complications from Parkinson's disease, the company said.

node.title: Children open up about what kindness and generosity mean to them
node.description: At an elementary school in Torrance, California, gratitude is part of the lesson plan.

node.title: Doctor answers viewers' questions on Omicron and the holidays
node.description: CBS News chief medical correspondent Dr. Jon LaPook joined "CBS Mornings" to answer viewers' questions about the latest phase of the pandemic and how Americans can stay safe this holiday season.

node.title: Kim Jong Un impersonator undeterred by threats
node.description: Kim Min Yong took his gig impersonating North Korea's dictator online, and despite criticism and even threats, he's determined to keep poking fun at Kim Jong Un.

node.title: Health officials anticipate spike in hospitalizations: "We are in a perfect storm"
node.description: As Omicron cases surge nationwide, experts believe it could be weeks before the country sees a downward trend in COVID-19 cases.

node.title: Floods are coming for America's business districts
node.description: Climate change means thousands of office buildings, malls and apartments are at greater risk of flooding, analysis finds.

node.title: FDA authorizes second COVID antiviral pill, if no alternative available
node.description: The White House expects millions of courses of the drug from Merck and Ridgeback Biotherapeutics by the end of January.

node.title: Number of workers filing for jobless aid near historic low
node.description: Only 205,000 Americans applied for unemployment last week, showing businesses remain reluctant to cut staff.
